tripleo_ansible/roles/octavia_undercloud.message:
Playbook runs as root user so files are root user owned. Probably need to set "owner" parameter here to "tripleo-admin".

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/community/crypto/openssh_keypair_module.html

/home/stack/overcloud-deploy/overcloud/config-download/overcloud/octavia-ansible/ssh_key:
total 8
drwxr-xr-x. 2 tripleo-admin root   54 Apr 26 13:31 .
drwxr-xr-x. 4 tripleo-admin root   88 Apr 26 13:35 ..
-rw-------. 1 root          root 3357 Apr 26 13:31 octavia_id_rsa
-rw-r--r--. 1 root          root  726 Apr 26 13:31 octavia_id_rsa.pub
What's the update/upgrade impact on this? Is it going to change keys for brownfield deployments?

there are 2 cases:
- update/upgrade from a commit before that one (i.e stable/train to master), existing ssh private key has been deleted from the undercloud, it's no longer usable by admins and by octavia, updating will create a new ssh key, and new amphorae (VMs) will be spawned with this ssh key
- update/upgrade for future releases, if the key already exists, it's not updated (openssh_keypair doesn't create a new key unless "force: yes" is passed)
As long as you're good with these scenarios we can proceed. Just want to highlight that this doesn't appear to be backwards compatible.

As discussed on our call, I will change the code such that a dedicated floating IP is not assigned to every subport, and instead we will create and delete floating IPs for subports whenever we want to. This is to prevent too many floating IPs from being created.

We are deleting the fip of the subport that is removed from trunk in line 350 and deleted in line 355. This subport will not be used for simulate_subport_connection in line 363, as it is deleted in line 355. We delete the fip to ensure that no dangling fips(with no ports associated) are present.
Line 363 selects random subports that are still present in the trunk, and pings those subports, not the ones that are deleted.
This may give you trunks without subports. So lets pop ineligible trunks at line 373

nit - can you at least log a warning that we are ignoring the failure to abort the migration?
Makes sense

we don't really "go back to the "manager". It's just the same service running, here the source nova-compute one. 

You could sat "Ensure job is aborted if still running before raising the exception so this would avoid the migration to be done and the libvirt guest to be resumed on the target while the instance record would still related to the source host.
Done, I'm fine with this repharing too.

we're then in a terrible situation if we wanted to abort the migration but we got an exception, because we don't know where and when it was having a problem, but that's fair enough, the instance will get an ERROR status.
Ack

there is a recover_method passed in that is used to by the monitor when libvirt report errors, could we reuse that in case of other errors as well? Interestingly nova passes in nova.compute.manager.ComputeManager._rollback_live_migration() as recover_method so I'm also wondering what is better here live_migration_abort or _rollback_live_migration .

I see, but _rollback_live_migration job is mainly doing db/infra cleanup via RPC,
Which will probably fail because we are here mainly due to DB / RPC / network failure.

So we can either:
-keep the change as it is because of that.

-eventually use call _rollback_live_migration instead of live_migration_abort
 but by adding live_migration_abort() at the beginning of _rollback_live_migration()
 with an additional flag _rollback_live_migration(..., force_abort=False)? I did not test.

Let me know if that way deserves to be explored.

Where _rollback_live_migration is called:
def _do_live_migration (before start of livemigration)
    try:                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
	self._waiting_live_migrations.pop(instance.uuid)                                                                                                                                                                             
    except KeyError:  
		  _rollback_live_migration
def _live_migration_monitor: (during jobstat monitor loop)
	elif info.type == libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_FAILED:
	   recover_method(...)
	elif info.type == libvirt.VIR_DOMAIN_JOB_CANCELLED:
	   recover_method(...)

If the DB or the RPC is down then self.live_migration_abort(instance) will fail at _set_migration_status() as that tries to update the database via RPC. Therefore live_migration_abort will never call self.driver.live_migration_abort(). So I don't think this patch actually solves the problem it intended to solve. If the DB or the RPC is down this patch will not cancel the ongoing migration on libvirt level.

https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virDomainAbortJob

> In case the job is a migration in a post-copy mode, virDomainAbortJob will report an error (see virDomainMigrateStartPostCopy for more details).

https://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virDomainMigrateStartPostCopy

> On the other hand once the guest is running on the destination host, the migration can no longer be rolled back because none of the hosts has complete state. 
> If this happens, libvirt will leave the domain paused on both hosts with VIR_DOMAIN_PAUSED_POSTCOPY_FAILED reason. It's up to the upper layer to decide what 
> to do in such case. Because of this, libvirt will refuse to cancel post-copy migration via virDomainAbortJob.

os_brick/cmd/nvmeof_agent/agent.py.message:
Rather than keep these OpenStack conf standards in the vendor-specific provisioner rest client (which is a mere lib, that is used outside of OpenStack context too) - I prefer keeping them in a vendor driver class (coming up in next patchset) - with the long term approach being that this vendor driver class is an "agent driver" that inherits/overrides an "agent driver interface" (rather than a "rest client inteface")

More on this in the comments in kioxia/rest_client.py
good idea, but rather than doing it in the rest client, I am handling this in the kumoscale agent driver coming up in next patchset.

os_brick/cmd/nvmeof_agent/kioxia/rest_cl.message:
I understand the need for this, but I rather keep all this out of the vendor-specific rest client class. Instead, I believe the best approach would be to wrap it up in an "agent driver" class (which will be the inheritable interface for other drivers, who will handle their own provisioner communication methods in whichever way they choose).

More on this in my response on line 287

I could not find anywhere that these kioxia_rest_client_opts get registered (ie. using CONF.register_opts()) - which is why I think I was getting "oslo_config.cfg.NoSuchOptError: no such option kioxia_prov_ip"

To solve this in the coming patchset, I added CONF.register_opts(kioxia_opts) below here in the vendor specific agent driver.
You're right, I forgot to register the options!

Understood, this definitely should be the general direction, what I was thinking is: a good long term approach (which I am working on now) is to create an interface class that wraps the logic calling these vendor-specific provisioner menthods, rather than inheriting and overriding a provisioner rest client class.

Meaning, rather than a common provisioner rest client interface (where methods such as ProvisionerRestClientClass.get_volume_by_uuid() will need to be inherited and overriden by each driver) - instead, wrapper methods in the agent that rely on provisioner communication will be the inheritable/overrideable interface methods, and it will be up to the driver devs to decide how to implement their provisioner communication parts (rather than being forced to follow the same "provisioner rest client" format as ours here)

So, to summarize what I am trying to say: rather than having a "rest client interface", the long term goal is to have an "agent driver interface".

I am making an attempt to create this agent driver interface in the following patchset, for now it is only dealing with the import and initialization of the provisioner rest client and entities, but over time, certain agent methods (the ones that rely on the provisioner communication which is vendor specific) - will be refactored into this interface class. (while the vendor-agnostic nvme and mdadm stuff will remain in the base agent).
Your approach sounds good.  It's more like dependency injection than inheritance, and I like that.

For now it was always used as a one value, mostly because high availability is achieved using routing (kumoscale provisioner address being a HA VIP).

I will have to double check if putting multiple addresses in is actually working, but it is what the kumoscale rest client expects. I think this improvement could be added as a followup that is kumoscale specific, for now i'm focusing on the generic agent architecture. But thank you for the observation and great suggestion, made a note to revisit this later.

When preparing this patch, I used the version of dpdk-devbind.py script that goes with the version of DPDK that Jiping's patches use. @Sean, I feel the bugs you pointed out are different cases. 

for https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1851545, the original issue is the original instance's pci device allocated to other new instance. But this won't happen for cyborg, cyborg won't allocate an allocated device to another arq.  And the nova pci device, the problem is we shouldn't release pci device when unshelve 'without' offload.

for https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1767797, the issue is about we didn't reschedule to new host with requested pci device. I think we tune this method make it work https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/conductor/manager.py#L967. But we needn't the original arq. We need to chose a new host with a free device, and then call the cyborg to create an new arq again. Then I think we need the NetworkRequest.arq_uuid again, to pass the new arq uuid to the nova-compute, then nova-compute will update the port binding profile with new arq uuid, then release the old one. This is what I'm guessing how it works when we implement the unshelve for cyborg.

So for the move operation, I think we needn't the original mapping info of port and arq, we need create new arq, and update the arq to the port. So then we needn't persistent the original port and arq mapping info when we create the instance.
We could no easily find which ARQ based on port's device_profile, we muse remember the ARQ. ARQ corresponding to one devices request per device_profile. we need this.
One more thing I just thought about is we should reject all the migration operation explicitly like this https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/api.py#L292

i just spoke about this with alex on irc
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/latest.log.html#t2021-03-10T12:17:32

tl;dr the issue with unshlve is we now supprot it with cyborg but the binding profile will not get updated.
in the case of sriov nova is correctly claiming the device but not upsdate the device porfile with the correct pci address
in the case of cyborg we would also need to create new arqs and update the port profile with those

since cyborg port will share the same code path as sriov port i suspec that we will get one of two behavior.

1 cyborg will delete teh arq form the port profile on shelve and on unshleve we will claim and bind the new arqs but
not update the profile so the guest will not get the cyborg device assigned, or enter an error state.
2 nova will not clear the old arq for the inctnace as part of shelve and we will try to look up the old arq which nolonger exits and fail.

what i discussed with alex was to not block this patch on this issue for now.
instead when i submit the patch to block shelve for instances ill make sure that include cyborg ports too
basically it will return the same 403 forbind error code we return today for shelving with a cycbog instance if the compute service version is less then 54
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/api.py#L4169
so for cyborg port ill return ForbiddenWithAccelerators and for sriov ill retrun a similar excptoin that also inherit form forbidin.

after we have blocked shelve with sriov and cybrog interfaces ill submit 2 more patches one to fix sriov which can be backported to all affected branches and a second to fix cyborg which might need your help since i dont have hardware i can test cyborg with.

the sriov patch will just ensure the pci_slot is update to the one we claimed before we generate teh xml
the cyborg one would have to do the same for the arqs.
the reason to ahve thos be two seperate patchs is for backports as the sriov one would have to go back multiple reelase and the cyborg one would only be needed for wallaby.

so for now im ok with you using this filed to store teh arqs 

next cycle i would like to see if we can stop using the port profile in general as part of the xml generaqtion process but that is a larger change that we should do spereatly form the cybrog feature. so i dont think we shoudl block this patch on that but we do need more unit tests as i noted seperatly.

specs/xena/approved/add-attachmentId-to-.message: This is... confusing. Could we use this new microversion to rename the existing ID to something like block_device_mapping_id? Otherwise we're left with a volumeAttachment that has an 'id' field, and also an 'attachmentId' field, and it's not clear what represents what.
Out of curiosity, can we make the 'id' here equal to the Cinder attachment id, and thus avoid the need for the new 'attachmentId' field altogether?

Right, I get that our resources usually have an id and/or a uuid, but I don't recall any other example where the resource is called 'foo', has an 'id' field, *and* a 'fooId' field. That's the part that I think could be clarified: volumeAttachment['id'] and volumeAttachment['attachmentId'] mean different things, and without being used to it or knowing the internals, it could be easy to confuse the two.

Anyways, I'm clearly not going to convince you of this, so I can remove my -1 :)

Appreciate that it is confusing but I'd rather not rename this from ``id``. We can easily call out in the docs that this is unique to the block device mapping record within Nova. nova/api/openstack/compute/attach_interf.message: I know this API isn't a proxy to Neutron but wouldn't 502 be better here?

I'm not sure it really matters that much between 502 and 503. Returning 502 every time we can't talk to another service seems a little bit like blame instead of reporting the actual problem. Especially in the case of placement, most users don't even know it exists or why we need to talk to it so saying "that other service you asked me to talk to is not available" seems like the wrong thing to me. It would be like us returning 502 because we failed to talk to libvirt which _technically_ happens over a socket. I guess the above makes me lean towards 503 if we're going with 5xx.

I think the thinking behind a 4xx code for the compute service being down was to legitimize the condition. It could be down for maintenance, we're still able to handle some requests for the instance, just not state changes right now, hence the "conflict" being that the instance is not in an actionable state. I don't think that's wrong.

If you agree with the above about instance actions, then I'm thinking that maybe 5xx for not being able to create right now is questionable. When apache returns 502 for something it can't proxy to, I think the expectation is "nothing here is going to work until the situation is resolved" and/or "don't try that again". You don't expect a GET to return 500 but a PUT would succeed, for example. I guess that's true for create specifically, meaning there's nothing the client can change about their request to make it successful, but it also seems maybe a little weird for POST to return 500 but PUT to return 2xx, so I dunno.

Let's discuss this. I've added other cores to the review now. 

I have no hard opinion. As you noted elsewhere 502 means some kind of proxying while in this case it is not a proxy it is just a dependency.

I quickly checked and nova returns HTTP 409 Conflict for the case when the instance action is invoked on an instance that is running on a host where the compute service is unavailable[1][2]. (This sounds bad :/) Or in case of hypervisor uptime we even return HTTP 400. 



[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/370830e9445c9825d1e34e60cca01fdfe88d5d82/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L970-L972
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/370830e9445c9825d1e34e60cca01fdfe88d5d82/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L1040

cinder/tests/unit/volume/drivers/ibm/tes.message: This doesn't test the case where data_reduction is not present in the dict at all.

You don't have to change it for this patch, but I think it's better to put the expected response in the data instead of putting conditional logic in the test.  What I mean is, if you set up the test like this:

    @ddt.data(('yes', True),
              ('Yes', True),
              ('YES', True),
              ('no', False),
              ('NO', False),
              ('', False))
    @ddt.unpack
    @mock.patch.object(storwize_svc_common.StorwizeHelpers,
                       'get_pool_attrs')
    def test_build_pool_stats_drp(self,
                                  is_drp_response, should_be_drp,
                                  get_pool_attrs):

then you can replace lines 5457-5460 with:

nova/virt/libvirt/config.py.message: Hmm, thinking on it more, if we're encrypting the client<->proxy channel then why is this needed? The instance lives on the server.

This adds an extra gate to get to the instance's console if you've somehow discovered the console url of someone else's instance. Example: you're at the office and a coworker is using their openstack instance via the vnc console. You peek over the cubicle wall and take a photo of their screen, zoomed in on the address bar, and then type it in, token and all, into your own browser. You'll get access to their console immediately.

If the console required a password, then you would be prompted for the password when you visit the console url you "stole". So you can't get in (unless you've spied on your coworker when they entered their password and have that too).

tox.ini.message:
because of 'usedevelop = True' (in line 7) the develop-inst phase runs, which installs networking-bagpipe *without* constraints (and re-installs some packages that conflicts with the newly installed packages' requirements - installed without constraints, in this case, if I'm not mistaken, neutron-lib, which pulls in latest neutron).
Long story short: the easiest fix is to install every dependency in tox's 'install' phase, so that nothing needs to be installed in 'develop-inst' phase.

specs/approved/ipa-telemetry.rst.message:
.. todo(...


I feel like we have sufficient detail for the most part.

As an operator, I would want to know which operation currently is executing. If we expose stages of each operation with system metrics, it would provide better insight about the runtime state, even if the precise progress is not achievable.

For example, if we are executing disk cleaning, how many disks are left, if they are wiping in parallel or in sequence? (perhaps we can even parse shred output to get iteration information, but this is out of scope)

And for deployment, are we downloading the image, writing the image, or installing bootloader? I think that is useful information for understanding the whole process, and if any stage is get stuck/slow, we could know.
Done

I concur, though wouldn't this progress reporting be a stand-alone spec? It seems to be more tied to the clean/deploy steps than to the the OS metrics...

Also, I'm a bit cautious not to over-engineer IPA beyond understanding. ;-)

I am concerned because the spec in the problem description talked about operation, time estimation, and from the runtime collected I think they are not adequate enough to address the problem.

If the spec only focuses providing system runtime information, I'm fine to not overbloat it :)
I'll assume this is done by checking something like to ``top`` at this time.

horizon/utils/memoized.py.message: Is there any use case where you wouldn't want to use weakref?

Ugh, it's actually worse. Because for flavors we can't cache globally like extensions, we want to cache per project, but without being able to specify which of the params to cache on that gets annoying.

So what we actually need is the following options:
1. max_size in LRU cache
2. cache_value expiry
3. create cache key from all, specific or no params.
Well, it's nice that you will keep the entry in the cache longer than the life of the reuqest, however, since the request is different now, you will never get a cache hit on it.

There are a few places where I think it may be beneficial to cache things longer term. LRU lets us do that safely. The issue is that while your patch to remove memoized_with_request does make the code a lot simpler, it makes those extension listing functions now get called for every request which we probably don't really want.

The missing part is an expiry option which could potentially be useful in some circumstances for things we want to cache but clear on a timer (e.g. in case the extensions change overnight).

Then we have the following options:
1. clear cached value as soon as all refs are gone
2. clear cached value as it is pushed out by newer ones
3. clear cached value on regular expiry period

With these we can look at even caching common values like instance flavors, etc, so we don't always go back to API calls, but we can clear the cache in a sensible manner.

The problem though is that in those cases we don't care about the arguments... at all. We care about the value alone and the 'key' in the cache would actually be the hash of the function.

So really we also need caching for:
4. cache the results of a function regardless of args/kwargs and expire the cached value after a certain time period

E.g. for a list_flavors type function we can decorate it as:

@memoized(expiry_time=86400, ignore_params=True)
def list_flavors(....):

Which would take a request etc as per normal, but use the function hash as the key (the cache size would only ever be 1).
nit: I would call this "decorate", because that is what it does.
Done
args is a list and kwargs is a dict — both are not hashable

/me facepalms

Yes I need to convert them to tuples... not just wrap them in tuples.
Could you add back the comments explaining why this is needed?
Yes! Will do.

As per note below:
This is where we check the value_expiry. We do actually use it, and that's why we need it in every cached value.
I think this could be slightly faster if you stored expiry_time as a timedelta object to begin with.
Good idea, I can put it with the cache and locks
I don't see much point in storing value_expiry with every single cache entry, since you never remove the expired items from the cache.

The point isn't to help with memory directly. Expiry lets us cache values like extension lists globally (cache size of 1) and expire it every 24 hrs. Or cache flavors per project, and expire them ever hr (or 30mins) in case the deployer has given the project any new specific custom flavors. The memory (and performance) benefit comes from smarter caching, which in those kind of cases expiry helps with.

And you're right, iterating the whole cache is an unlikely scenario, mostly it should just be a few, or even more likely none since we're more likely to hit max_size well before expiry unless horizon isn't being used much.

I don't think we'd hit expiry often in normal cases, so it's only useful when we do something different with the get_key_func value. We can include clearing the expiry items, but I don't think we gain anything, and the current logic is much clearer/simpler for just ensuring an expired value is never returned.

Memory should mostly be handled by us using the caches smarter, setting a sensible max_size for the LRU ejection per function decorated, and hopefully by weakrefs working as intended when used.

I did originally think about removing them, but the problem there is that to do so would require iterating over the whole cache every call and comparing times, noting the expired keys, and then after checking, removing those keys. This would also potentially run into concurrency issues unless we did key locking when removing them.

So, the solution I went with:
- Let the LRU nature of the cache handle getting rid of old keys/values
- the expiry serves not to empty the cache, but to invalidate the value

So when we check for a key, and if we already have that key, THEN we check for the expiry. If it hasn't expired, we return right way, else, we throw a keyerror and call the function again, and recache it (see note above).

Alright, what I'll do split the LRU parts into a smaller patch specific for capping memory usage, and I'll add a blueprint for what I'd like to expand it into. Then this patch can turn into an example of what I'd like to do.

Sorry, but I fail to see how this behavior helps with memory use.

You don't have to iterate over all values, since they are sorted by use — you only need to iterate until you find the first non-expired value, I think?

I see. But I don't think memoized should be used for this. We mostly use it as a convenience for avoiding repeating api calls within one request.

What you are trying to build here is an elaborate caching system, which — I admit — would be a nice thing to have, but which should be a little better planned and thought out, including different cache invalidation scenarios and performance testing.

If possible, I would prefer this change to be limited to only introducing the LRU cache size limit, since that is what we need to fix the memory problems, and defer the more elaborate improvements, pending a design document and so on.

I completely understand that it's a very interesting problem, but those kinds of systems can grow arbitrarily complex, without really providing much advantage. Let's try to limit the complexity for the sake for ease of maintenance in the future.

we should validate this header using 

  self.get_and_validate_policy_index(req)
might be worth always returning this header in response even if not in request
OK, so this has been included ever since gen_resp_headers was a thing: https://github.com/openstack/swift/commit/4321bb0

And shard responses have used this ever since the container learned how to make them: https://github.com/openstack/swift/commit/723eac9

So shard responses *always* send back SPI, and it's always the SPI *from DB metadata*.
We do something similar with objects...

... but then we're sure to update it to match what was actually queried if they differ. Maybe this would be better/more clear as

 if requested_policy_index is not None:
     resp_headers['X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index'] = requested_policy_index
 # else, the container's policy was set in gen_resp_headers

?

Might even be worth using a different header; maybe

 X-Backend-Queried-Storage-Policy-Index

or even

 X-Backend-Record-Storage-Policy-Index

for some degree of symmetry with X-Backend-Record-Type.

Though then I'd be torn about whether we ought to return it all the time (to be explicit) or only if it differs from X-Backend-Storage-Policy-Index (to push us a little more to keep the upgrade path in mind).

As we talked about this morning. Having a different one when it isn't the same is warming on me. Esp if we ever want to use this feature for anything else. You said you managed to poison your cache while playing around because of a different spi returning from a shard.

We also take for granted that we use the resp from the root request and use its x-backend-storage-policy-index knowing it's what it must have in it's DB. And then we go write over the shards response, so now we can't trust shard return values. So it might be nice to know that the x-backend-storage-policy-index is the containers serialized version, but the object that are returned belong to x-backend-requested-storage-policy-index (which I like).

I kinda like the requested-* but record-* also makes sense as it does have prior usage.
I'm getting less and less convinced of this -- at any rate, I needed to do more digging than I'd originally expected ;-)

+1 on balance I think I prefer this header being returned unconditionally for object records. We could then infer upgraded server from the presence of the header, as opposed to 'maybe not upgraded, or maybe same policy as requested'.

Becasue these queries/sub reqs to the shards go via app.handle_request. This code can be somewhat recursive. So if we make a call to a root container, that then goes to a shard that also happens to be sharding, then it'll then make calls to the new shards to get the data.

In this case we have to be careful of the SPI to use. The only adding the policy index if isn't already in the req, ensures that we are only using the root spi, which is what we want.

The resp given here is the response from the root container, and so how we're getting the "correct" SPI.

The whole placing it in headers and not in the req directly is because that's what we are doing with other headers we want to override, then they get .update(headers) as clay mentions elsewhere. It could be added to the req, but was just matching the current way we did things.. but turns out makes it easy to test what we added/overwrote.

so in this loop "resp" is the "root_resp" and "shard_resp" is the response from the shards

Yes, the checking is still needed. The following is a demonstration of who this works:
>>> params_supported = ['C', 'OU', 'O', 'ST', 'CN', 'L']
>>> subject_dict={'C':'CA', 'OU':'WRS'}
>>> [i in params_supported for i in subject_dict.keys()]
[True, True]
>>> all([i in params_supported for i in subject_dict.keys()])
True
>>>
>>> subject_dict={'CC':'CA', 'OUU':'WRS'}
>>> [i in params_supported for i in subject_dict.keys()]
[False, False]
>>> all([i in params_supported for i in subject_dict.keys()])
False
>>>
